current_fact.fact_text: In 2003, Turkish Airlines Flight 634 crashed during approach to Diyarbakır Airport in dense fog, killing 75 of the 80 people aboard. The accident drew attention to how weather, technology, and human decision-making intertwine in the final seconds of flight.

episode.title: Morning Drops #20 - Hitchhiking Poland
episode.description: Yasmin takes you back to the summer of 2020, when borders were still uncertain and a long-held wish to visit Poland finally came true. Through four tracks, tracing her journey from a stranger's couch in Poznań to the peaks of Zakopane.

current_fact.match_reason: A tragic flight into fog is contrasted with an episode about overland travel and hitchhiking, underlining how different modes of journey can feel in terms of vulnerability, risk, and connection to place.

queue.fact_text: On 8 January 2009, a magnitude 6.1 earthquake struck near Cinchona in northern Costa Rica, triggering landslides that destroyed villages and killed 15 people. The quake reshaped the landscape and reminded scientists how mountainous tropical regions can amplify seismic hazards.

episode.title: Morning Drops #29 - Morning Dubs
episode.description: Recorded while still processing Houghton Festival. One of the mornings there, waking up in the woods to a reggae DJ set — no phone signal, just trees, music, and loved ones. A slow selection of reggae, dub, and morning rhythms. Dubs instead of drops. Start your day slow — with space to breathe.
songs: The Gaylads - Joy in the Morning
King Tubby - King Tubby Meets the Rockers Uptown

queue.match_reason: Earthquakes literally shake the ground, while dub and roots reggae often explore themes of 'Babylon' and unstable worlds; this spacious, echoing soundscape mirrors the reverberations of a seismic shock.

queue.fact_text: On this day in 1900, U.S. President William McKinley placed Alaska under military rule, treating the vast, sparsely populated territory as a strategic outpost rather than a typical civilian region. The move underscored how frontiers are often governed first as garrisons before they become homes.

episode.title: Morning Drops #28 - Under Scottish Skies
episode.description: Gaia shares a personal moment of transition — a shift in seasons, in rhythm, and in life. From this space of quiet change comes a musical journey through Scotland: not the usual names, but voices that speak from the edges. A personal ritual and a small act of curiosity: an invitation to notice what grounds us when everything moves.
songs: Paolo Nutini - Pencil Full of Lead

queue.match_reason: Remote, rugged Alaska mirrors the wild, edge-of-the-map landscapes evoked by Scottish folk and Celtic rock, both places where weather, land, and politics feel larger than life.

queue.fact_text: In 1940, Britain introduced nationwide food rationing, limiting sugar, bacon, and butter as German U-boats threatened vital supply lines. The policy reshaped everyday cooking, inspired inventive wartime recipes, and showed how a whole society can change its eating habits under pressure.

episode.title: Morning Drops #01 - Timeless Legacy
episode.description: Gaia guides us through timeless music to start the morning with the right foot! The first episode of the Morning Drops series — classic sounds that never fade.
songs: Roberta Flack - Killing me softly with his song

queue.match_reason: In a time of scarcity, people leaned on small, sustaining pleasures; warm, timeless soul and jazz‑funk mirrors the comfort and resilience found in simple, shared meals under rationing.

queue.fact_text: On 8 January 1912, San Diego passed an ordinance restricting street speech, sparking a months-long "free speech fight" between the radical Industrial Workers of the World and business interests. The conflict turned violent, making it one of the bloodiest struggles over the right to speak in American history.

episode.title: Morning Drops #08 - (un)Boxing
episode.description: An episode about breaking free from expectations and labels. Music that helps us unbox ourselves and embrace who we truly are.
songs: Kendrick Lamar - The Blacker the Berry

queue.match_reason: A fight for the right to speak in public resonates with an episode about breaking out of boxes and speaking one’s truth, powered by politically sharp, consciousness‑raising hip‑hop.

queue.fact_text: In 1889, inventor Herman Hollerith received a U.S. patent for his punched-card tabulating machine, designed to speed up the census by encoding data as holes in stiff paper cards. His system became a foundation for early computing and ultimately evolved into the company that would become IBM.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Nomophobia
episode.description: Yasmin reflects on what happened when she recently lost her phone and why it felt freeing. A dive into the psychology of our relationship with smartphones: from nomophobia (the fear of being without a phone), to digital burnout and cognitive overload, to the surprising benefits of boredom and the brain's default mode network. An invitation to rethink how we connect and disconnect.

queue.match_reason: Hollerith’s punch cards were an ancestor of modern digital life; an episode that questions our relationship with computers and phones is a perfect echo of where that information revolution began.

queue.fact_text: On 8 January 1735, George Frideric Handel’s opera “Ariodante” premiered at London’s Covent Garden, weaving a tale of love, betrayal, and mistaken identity. Though not his most famous work today, it showcased his gift for emotionally charged arias and complex characters.

episode.title: Sedna FM #04 - Queen of Spades
episode.description: Tuning in from the planet of irrational love. Exploring love's most vulnerable side — the kind that awakens the child within us. A diverse music selection ranging from electric blues to downtempo, soul, and jazz. A tribute to the feeling that has moved artists to create the most beautiful works. Love makes us vulnerable, and there is no art without vulnerability.
songs: Alabama Shakes - Gimme All Your Love
Queens of the stone age - Make it wit chu
Etta James - I'd Rather Go Blind
Eric Clapton - Have you ever loved a woman

queue.match_reason: An 18th‑century opera about tangled love and vulnerability pairs beautifully with a multi‑genre episode dedicated to love’s irrational, heart‑exposing power.

queue.fact_text: On this day in 1975, Ella T. Grasso was sworn in as Governor of Connecticut, becoming the first woman elected governor in the United States who did not follow her husband into the role. Her victory marked a milestone for women’s political leadership in American history.

episode.title: Morning Drops #04 - Bars With Balls
episode.description: Yasmin dives into Women's Day through the voices of four incredible female rappers. Morning fire from the magic planet of Sedna FM — move your hands up and down with us. Hip hop culture through a feminine lens.
songs: Little Simz - Point and Kill (feat. Obongjayar)

queue.match_reason: A pioneering female governor is celebrated alongside an episode amplifying powerful women in hip‑hop, both charting new territory in spaces traditionally dominated by men.

queue.fact_text: On 8 January 1956, during Operation Auca, five American missionaries were killed by Waorani people in the Ecuadorian Amazon shortly after attempting first contact. The encounter, tragic and controversial, later led to closer relationships and conversations about cultural respect, faith, and indigenous autonomy.

episode.title: Morning Drops #16 - The Sound of Tuareg
episode.description: A journey into the sound of the Tuareg: from traditional chants and desert rituals to the electrified rhythms of exile and resistance. Music shaped by sand, memory, and survival.

queue.match_reason: A fraught first contact in the rainforest is paired with an episode centered on another indigenous people, the Tuareg, encouraging slower, more respectful listening to cultures often misrepresented or misunderstood.

queue.fact_text: In 1877, Lakota leader Crazy Horse fought his last battle against the U.S. Cavalry at Wolf Mountain in the Montana Territory. The clash took place in deep winter, symbolizing both the physical harshness and the historical end of open resistance on the northern Plains.

episode.title: Morning Drops #35 - Thailand
episode.description: Recorded in Koh Samui, Thailand, where Yasmin and her friend Patricia spent more than two intense weeks training Muay Thai and Western boxing. Between sweat, rhythm, and sea breeze, they share reflections on discipline, friendship, and the beauty of movement - with a soundtrack that connects Thai sounds to the flow of daily practice.
songs: Burna Boy - Cheat on Me (feat. Dave)

queue.match_reason: A legendary warrior’s final stand connects metaphorically with an episode about martial arts, discipline, and embodied struggle—translating battlefield courage into the controlled arena of training and sport.

queue.fact_text: On 8 January 1806, the Battle of Blaauwberg near Cape Town ended with British victory and the transformation of the Dutch Cape Colony into the British Cape Colony. This coastal battle reshaped control of a key resupply point on the route between Europe and Asia.

episode.title: Morning Drops #11 - Mediterranean Boat
episode.description: Gaia invites you to embark on a musical voyage across the Mediterranean. Exploring music from different countries shared by people who call them home. A warm, sun-soaked journey through coastal sounds.
songs: Fabrizio De André - Crêuza de mä

queue.match_reason: A naval-access battle over a strategic cape matches an episode built around sea routes and coastal cultures, trading cannon fire for shared songs that travel across the water.

queue.fact_text: In 1946, Soviet official Andrei Zhdanov submitted to a Finnish court the interrogation report of German General Erich Buschenhagen, including details of prewar contacts between Finnish and German militaries and a copy of Hitler’s Barbarossa plan. The documents became key evidence in Finland’s controversial war-responsibility trials.

episode.title: Morning Drops #25 - A Trip-Hop Journey
episode.description: Hosted by friend Lorenzo, a journey through the roots and evolution of trip-hop. From Bristol's early experiments with Massive Attack and Tricky, to DJ Shadow's cinematic sampling in California, and Thievery Corporation's global downtempo grooves in Washington D.C. — exploring how this genre blurred boundaries and reshaped electronic music.
songs: Tricky - Hell Is Round the Corner
DJ Shadow - Midnight in a Perfect World

queue.match_reason: Cold-war intrigue, secret plans, and courtroom revelations pair well with the cinematic, shadowy atmosphere of trip‑hop, a genre that often feels like the soundtrack to a political thriller.

queue.fact_text: On 8 January 871, Æthelred I and his younger brother Alfred—later known as Alfred the Great—led the West Saxon army in repelling an invasion by Danelaw Vikings. These early battles against Scandinavian raiders shaped the survival of the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms.

episode.title: Morning Drops #36 - Women of Rock
episode.description: A tribute to the women who shaped the sound of rock, the ones who picked up a guitar and refused to ask for permission. The conversation unfolds in Italian, led by Gaia and her father. A dialogue between generations and a reminder that the pulse of rock has always belonged to anyone brave enough to play it loud. Distortion, rhythm, freedom.
songs: Joan Jett & The Blackhearts - I Love Rock 'n Roll

queue.match_reason: Sword‑clashing shield walls and roaring guitar riffs share the same energy of defiance; this episode’s fierce, driving rock channels the battle‑spirit of resisting invaders.

queue.fact_text: On this day in 1996, in Kinshasa’s bustling market district, an An-32 crash turned a normal day of street trading into chaos in seconds. Many victims never even saw the plane, illustrating how modern technology can carry risks far beyond its intended path.

episode.title: Morning Drops #24 - The Rise Of Afrobeat
episode.description: An exploration of the rise of Afrobeat, tracing its roots and evolution as a genre that blends African rhythms with jazz, funk, and highlife. A celebration of the infectious energy and cultural significance of this influential musical movement.

queue.match_reason: Kinshasa is one of Africa’s great musical capitals; pairing this tragedy with a celebration of Afrobeat honors the continent’s resilience, creativity, and sonic power in the face of hardship.

queue.fact_text: On 8 January 2003, Turkish Airlines Flight 634’s doomed descent into fog near Diyarbakır became a stark reminder of how quickly conditions can shift from normal to fatal. Investigations led to changes in instrument landing procedures and training across the industry.

episode.title: Morning Drops #42 - The Joy Of Learning
episode.description:
Hosted by Yasmin, this Morning Drop explores learning as a lifelong process, focusing on persistence, repetition, and the emotional landscape that comes with challenging oneself over time.

Through personal stories and scientific insights, the episode looks at how learning reshapes the brain, generates joy through effort, and why progress often arrives after confusion and frustration. It reflects on the so-called delayed pleasure effect, the role of dopamine in motivation, and how curiosity and learning support long-term wellbeing.

The episode also questions our cultural relationship with failure and invites a softer, more realistic approach to learning, one that accepts mistakes as part of growth and sees persistence as a quiet form of strength.

Mood: reflective, grounded, quietly hopeful
Music genre: alternative rock, hip hop, electronic, neo-soul, drill

A space to listen slowly and stay with the process.

queue.match_reason: The painful lessons drawn from an aviation accident connect with an episode about learning, mistakes, and slow improvement—zooming out from individual tragedy to systemic growth.

queue.fact_text: On 8 January 2005, after its violent impact with an undersea mountain, the USS San Francisco limped back to port and was eventually repaired, returning to service. The incident highlighted how little of the seabed we have actually mapped, even in regions traveled by high-tech vessels.

episode.title: Morning Drops #40 - Diving With Orcas
episode.description: Yasmin's friend Caroline takes us beyond the polar circle, into the Arctic waters of Norway, where orcas and humpback whales gather each winter. A personal journey shaped by a quiet obsession with orcas, from Patagonia to the icy fjords of the north. The soundscape moves gently between cinematic swells and soft, rhythmic pulses — echoing the cold light of Arctic mornings and the grace of underwater encounters.

queue.match_reason: Both the submarine collision and this episode dwell in the hidden world beneath the waves—one a story of catastrophe, the other of awe and connection with marine life.

queue.fact_text: On 8 January 2023, thousands of supporters of former president Jair Bolsonaro stormed Brazil’s Congress, Supreme Court, and presidential palace in Brasília. The coordinated attack on democratic institutions drew comparisons to other recent assaults on capitols and raised fears about the fragility of modern democracies.

episode.title: Morning Drops #39 - Moving Meditation
episode.description: An episode inspired by how travel helps us see more clearly. Stepping into new places opens the mind, shifts perspective. The music moves through balearic warmth, boogie grooves, world and latin-folk influences, and touches of new wave — a selection built to follow the quiet changes that happen when you're out of your usual rhythm.
songs: España Circo Este - Dormo poco e sogno molto
Talking Heads - This Must Be the Place (Naive Melody)

queue.match_reason: A chaotic, violent march on institutions is contrasted with an episode about slowing down, traveling, and shifting perspective—hinting that movement and reflection can open minds more than mobs ever will.

queue.fact_text: On 8 January 1994, when Valeri Polyakov’s mission began, doctors planned to study how more than a year without gravity would change his muscles, bones, and mind. His 437-day stay aboard Mir remains a benchmark for planning future journeys to Mars and beyond.

episode.title: Sedna FM #02 - Destination Sedna
episode.description: Continuing the Sedna FM journey together with family and friends! Episode two of the main series — exploring new musical territories and deepening the connection with our listeners. A collective voyage through sound.
songs: Odion Iruoje - Identify With Your Roots
Depeche mode - world in my eyes (Oil Tank Mix)

queue.match_reason: A record‑breaking voyage in orbit aligns with this episode’s theme of collective journeys into new territories, with ‘Breathe’ and cosmic synth textures evoking the feeling of drifting toward distant planets.

published.fact_text: In 1994, Russian cosmonaut Valeri Polyakov boarded Soyuz TM-18 bound for the Mir space station and did not return to Earth for 437 days. His mission became the longest single continuous stay in space, a human experiment in endurance and adaptation to microgravity.

episode.title: Morning Drops #03 - Space Shift
episode.description: Gaia invites you to shift your mindset with a simple yet powerful reflection: What if we saw emptiness not as a void but as space to create? An energising and feel-good selection of tracks, the perfect way to ease into your day and set the tone for the week ahead.
songs: Willy J Healey - Woke Up Smiling
The Strokes - You Only Live Once

published.match_reason: A story about turning the emptiness of orbit into a laboratory for human potential pairs naturally with an episode themed around reimagining ‘empty’ space as creative possibility.

published.fact_text: On 8 January 1973, the Soviet Union launched Luna 21, a spacecraft that delivered the Lunokhod 2 rover to the Moon. The rover spent months trundling across the lunar surface, photographing craters and testing the strange, powdery soil of our satellite.

episode.title: Evening Flows #01 - Yasmin - Crescendo in the Medina
episode.description: The first Evening Flow episode comes from Yasmin. It starts deep in the medina, slow, mysterious, textured, and grows into a liberating dance across sub-Saharan landscapes. A journey through ambient soundscapes, Arabic melodies, Afro-Latin rhythms, and funky highlife grooves.
songs: David Visan & Carlos Campos - Crystal Heart
Evan Mars - Ya Zareef Al Tool
Dele Sosimi & Medlar - You No Fit Touch Am (Medlar Remix)

published.match_reason: Luna 21’s glide into the lunar night fits the slow, mysterious rise of this evening mix, even echoing in track titles like “Solar Wind.”

published.fact_text: In 2004, the RMS Queen Mary 2 was christened as the largest ocean liner ever built, a floating city designed for days-long crossings of the Atlantic. Its size and elegance revived the romance of sea travel in an age dominated by airplanes.

episode.title: Morning Drops #31 - Sailing With Germans
episode.description: From the deck of a sailing boat, hosted by Yasmin and her special guests. A week at sea with six Germans, each with their own stories, songs, and ways of moving through the waves. From shared meals to unexpected laughter, from quiet resilience to sun-soaked joy — a collection of voices and tracks that reflect what it means to journey together.
songs: Ben Howard - Keep Your Head Up

published.match_reason: A majestic ocean liner and an episode recorded on a sailing boat both celebrate life at sea, waves as a rhythm, and the quiet magic of long journeys over water.

published.fact_text: On 8 January 2005, the nuclear submarine USS San Francisco struck an uncharted undersea mountain near Guam while traveling at high speed. Despite catastrophic damage to her bow, the crew managed to bring the vessel to the surface and save nearly everyone aboard.

episode.title: Morning Drops #33 - Immerse
episode.description: An analogy between diving, one of Gaia's great passions, and the act of immersing in life itself. A reflection on what happens when we go below the surface: when we let ourselves be fully present. From moments of calm suspension to warm, rhythmic flow, the selection moves like water — fluid, organic, and alive. An invitation to slow down, listen deeper, and float.
songs: Pino D'Angiò - Un Po' d'Uva e un Liquore

published.match_reason: A near‑fatal collision in the deep ocean contrasts sharply with this episode’s meditative take on immersion, inviting reflection on how differently ‘going below the surface’ can feel.

published.fact_text: In 1996, an Antonov An-32 cargo plane overshot the runway in Kinshasa and ploughed into a bustling market, killing over 200 people on the ground. The tragedy highlighted how aviation disasters can devastate communities that never set foot on an aircraft.

episode.title: Morning Drops #43 - Looking Back
episode.description:
In this first Morning Drop of 2026, Yasmin opens a space for quiet reflection on the nature of transitions. The episode traces a personal journey that began three years ago, when a sudden injury on New Year’s Day turned a desire for movement into a mandatory season of stillness.

Through the story of a broken knee and the slow process of relearning to walk, the narrative explores the difference between being strong and being aware. It touches on the vulnerability of the body, the unexpected joy found in daily progress, and the warmth that comes from finally allowing oneself to accept help. The musical selection mirrors this path of recovery, moving from the uncertainty of change to the steady rhythm of healing.

Mood: Reflective, Resilient, Grounded
Music genre: Indie Pop, Cinematic, World, Soul

We invite you to listen deeply and find comfort in your own pace.
songs: Kelly Finnigan - I Don't Wanna Wait
Goran Bregović & Iggy Pop - This Is a Film

published.match_reason: A devastating, sudden accident is paired with a reflective episode about injury, recovery, and the slow process of healing after life is violently interrupted.

published.fact_text: On 8 January 1989, British Midland Flight 92 crashed beside the M1 motorway near Kegworth after the crew shut down the wrong engine following a malfunction. The disaster became a landmark case in how airlines redesign training and cockpit communication to prevent human-factor failures.

episode.title: Morning Drops #05 - Electric Shock
episode.description: An energizing episode with electrifying sounds to wake you up and get you moving. High energy tracks that deliver a jolt of musical electricity to start your day.

published.match_reason: The sudden, jarring shock of an aviation disaster connects with this episode’s high‑voltage, guitar‑driven intensity, mirroring the raw surge of adrenaline when things go violently wrong.

published.fact_text: In 2003, Turkish Airlines Flight 634 crashed during approach to Diyarbakır Airport in dense fog, killing 75 of the 80 people aboard. The accident drew attention to how weather, technology, and human decision-making intertwine in the final seconds of flight.

episode.title: Morning Drops #20 - Hitchhiking Poland
episode.description: Yasmin takes you back to the summer of 2020, when borders were still uncertain and a long-held wish to visit Poland finally came true. Through four tracks, tracing her journey from a stranger's couch in Poznań to the peaks of Zakopane.

published.match_reason: A tragic flight into fog is contrasted with an episode about overland travel and hitchhiking, underlining how different modes of journey can feel in terms of vulnerability, risk, and connection to place.
